solution:
Since
\[f(2x + 1) = f \left( 2 \left( x + \frac{1}{2} \right) \right),\]the graph of $y = f(2x + 1)$ is produced by taking the graph of $y = f(x)$ and compressing it horizontally by a factor of $\frac{1}{2},$ then shifting it $\frac{1}{2}$ units to the left.  The correct graph is $\boxed{\text{A}}.$

In particular, to produce the graph of $y = f(2x + 1),$ we do not compress it horizontally by a factor of $\frac{1}{2},$ then shift it 1 unit to the left; the function produced by this transformation would be
\[y = f(2(x + 1)) = f(2x + 2).\]
